awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Investigation of mechanisms underlying pathological rhythms in parkinsonian basal ganglia - A mathematical modeling study
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building a research program. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to North Carolina A&T State University has potential broader and societal impact in a number of areas. The project focuses on developing a mathematical model to understand the mechanisms underlying deep brain stimulation, a therapy used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. Undergraduate students as well as high school students will gain research experiences.  

The effectiveness of deep brain stimulation in Parkinson's disease has been linked to the destruction of pathological rhythmicity in basal ganglia. To find a more effective deep brain stimulation procedure, it is crucial to use appropriate neuronal network models that are able to produce intermittently synchronized oscillatory dynamics observed in parkinsonian patients. As the only excitatory nucleus in the basal ganglia, the subthalamic nucleus plays an important role in the dynamics of basal ganglia and is a standard target for deep brain stimulation in Parkinson's disease. Recent experiments have identified a set of ionic currents that are responsible for various rhythmic bursting patterns in subthalamic nucleus neurons. This research will develop a new computational model for the subthalamic nucleus that comprises key currents and then set up network models, namely an updated basal ganglia network model and an extended cortex-basal ganglia-thalamus model. By performing numerical and mathematical analyses, the research will study how intrinsic neuronal properties and network properties in basal ganglia incorporate to generate intermittently synchronized rhythms. This project will enhance the understanding of the mechanisms underlying pathological rhythms in parkinsonian basal ganglia and deep brain stimulation procedures. The research may also lead to the discovery of more effective methods to break the intermittently synchronized rhythms in parkinsonian states with a minimal amount of stimulation intervention.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematical model of subthalamic nucleus neuron

The subthalamic nucleus (STN) is involved in motor behaviors and various other brain functions. Pathological activities in STN contribute to the motor symptoms of Parkinson?s disease. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanistic basis of electrical activity in STN neurons. In this project, the PI developed a conductance-based single-compartment model of STN neurons, which is able to generate characteristic activity patterns observed in experiments including hyperpolarization-induced bursts and post-inhibitory rebound bursts. The PI explored how different membrane channels interact with each other to give rise to various activity patterns in a single cell. The PI performed a bifurcation analysis using slow variables in membrane currents and showed how calcium currents can promote different types of bursting, particularly in response to inhibitory input. The study also emphasized the importance of slow calcium currents in subthalamic cells in Parkinson?s disease, which are known for their bursting electrical activity in the basal ganglia. This STN model can be readily used to construct neuronal network models within the brain to study the mechanism underlying characteristic beta rhythms observed in Parkinsonian basal ganglia. Specific tangible merits include a deeper understanding of how rhythmic bursts in STN cells contribute to the generation of the characteristic intermittent synchrony in the STN-GPe (external globus pallidus) network. Development of an extended cortex-STN-GPe network model will also enhance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying deep brain stimulation and may contribute to the development of more effective methods to break the synchronized bursting rhythms in parkinsonian states with a minimal amount of stimulation intervention. 

Social stress induced neural network reconfiguration in zebrafish  

Zebrafish form a stable social relationship and the behavior patterns differ according to their social ranks. The PI worked on a neurocomputational model of zebrafish to investigate the effects of social status on neuromodulatory systems that drive motor activity. The PI first investigated how social status differentially affects learning in the context of habituation, a well-characterized form of non-associative learning. The modeling study showed that social status affects habituative learning in zebrafish, which could be mediated by a summative neuromodulatory input to the escape circuit. We then investigated the role of the endocannabinoid system (ECS) in mediating the differences in motor activities. From the modeling study we found that social status influences the ECS to regulate the balance in synaptic strength between excitatory and inhibitory inputs to control the excitability of motor behaviors. Results from this study enhanced our understanding of the mechanisms by which social stress affects cellular and biochemical plasticity among different neuromodulators that work collectively to produce different motor behaviors. More specifically, the results described a novel mechanism of how network dynamics is reconfigured and how the interactions of neuromodulatory components and inputs from higher brain regions result in various behavioral patterns. Humans and zebrafish share around 70% of similar genes, and about 80% of human disease-causing genes have a zebrafish counterpart. Thus, results in zebrafish will advance our understanding of the complex dynamical mechanisms of major nervous system malfunctions in other organisms, including humans. Therefore, this project has the potential for very broad social and economic impacts and health benefits.

Respiratory network

 Rhythmic activity patterns arise in various regions of the central nervous system and have been implicated in a variety of critical and cognitive functions. Central pattern generator (CPG) circuits represent a natural subject for computational and mathematical study. There has been extensive work on this topic in the literature, but plenty of questions about CPGs have not yet been addressed. Three-unit neuronal network with all-to-all inhibitory synaptic coupling used in this study often arises as building blocks of CPG models because of the prevalence of inhibitory interneurons within these networks and because mutual inhibition provides a natural framework for producing the sequential activation patterns seen in muscle groups driven by CPG outputs. One of the observed propagating solutions appeared to be contrary to the network architecture and was characterized by a sudden ?turn-around? of trajectories during fast transitions between quasi-stable states. By considering a linear, reduced form of the model system that preserves the solution structure, we were able to perform a thorough analysis of the oscillations, which revealed novel adaptive escape and adaptive release phase transition mechanisms. The main contributions of this work include a bifurcation study that reveals the existence of a large parameter range over which bistability in oscillation patterns occurs, a mathematical analysis of the mechanisms involved in generating these patterns, and an explanation of the role of fast and slow timescale interaction in shaping phase transitions in this model. The use of linear models allowed us to proceed with the mathematical analysis, which was critical for obtaining a variety of mechanistic insights and for providing evidence that the effects revealed by our numerical simulations are valid.
